Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A critical bearing is screeching loudly and threatening an immediate breakdown.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I knelt beside the conveyor, the screech of the failing bearing drowning out everything else. I knew it was Mom—she always texted around this time, wanting to know how my day was going, if I’d eaten, if I was okay. I’d promised her I’d reply quickly, keep her updated, especially after Dad’s health scare last month. But right now, the machine was on the verge of seizing up, and if I didn’t get it cleaned and the bearing replaced, the whole line would grind to a halt. My supervisor’s words echoed in my head: “We can’t afford downtime. Stay focused.” I could almost feel the weight of both expectations pressing on my shoulders—my parents needing reassurance, my job demanding my undivided attention. My hands hovered between the wrench and my phone, heart pounding, torn between being the reliable son and the dependable repairer.
